subject: Re: (unknown)
msgSnippet: Hi guys, Believe it or not, I had the same problem once. I fixed it by typing out the full class name in the function definition ( junit.framework.Test ).
messageBody:
Hi guys,

Believe it or not, I had the same problem once. I fixed it by typing
out the full class name in the function definition
("junit.framework.Test").

--Patrick Parker

--- In junit@y..., Sameer Ajmani <ajmani@m...> wrote:
> A simpler solution is just to put junit.jar ahead fo your
developer's
> classes in your classpath.
>
> --Sameer
>
> > Within the same package as where the MapTest.java was, existed a
> > Test.class (and Test.java). The developer's Test.class did not
have
> > the appropriate run method, and therefore could not work.
> >
> > Not that anyone would ever have this problem starting out with
junit,
> > but if you happen to take over code from developers and they've
> > created a Test.class within the package, just delete or rename the
> > Test.class and all will go back into the green.
